docs.abstract: We thought that once we decided on adoption, out of the ether, a child would appear. I have been wrong before, but never quite this wrong.
docs.snippet: We thought that once we decided on adoption, out of the ether, a child would appear. I have been wrong before, but never quite this wrong.

docs.lead_paragraph: I am finally going to meet the birth mother, at her request, at a mall in Paramus, N.J.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nov. 30, 8:28 p.m. | Updated See Apple's response to this issue.

headline.main: Apple's Siri Stumbles Over an Abortion Question

docs.abstract: Siri, Apple's virtual assistant software, appears to draw a blank when some users ask it to suggest an abortion clinic. A founder of Siri said it was not clear whether its inability to produce answers to specific queries was a deliberate decision on Apple's part.
docs.snippet: Siri, Apple's virtual assistant software, appears to draw a blank when some users ask it to suggest an abortion clinic. A founder of Siri said it was not clear whether its inability to produce answers to specific queries was a deliberate decision on...

headline.main: Apple's Siri Stumbles Over an Abortion Question

docs.abstract: Siri, Apple’s virtual assistant software, appears to draw a blank when some users ask it to suggest an abortion clinic.
docs.snippet: Siri, Apple’s virtual assistant software, appears to draw a blank when some users ask it to suggest an abortion clinic.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a dolphin is within weeks of giving birth, she faces a drastic increase in drag and changes the way she swims.

headline.main: Different Strokes With a Baby on Board
headline.print_headline: Different Strokes With a Baby on Board

docs.abstract: Analysis published by marine biologist Shawn R Noren in the Journal of Experimental Biology finds female dolphins swim differently during the last weeks of their pregnancy in order to counteract drag that results from their increased girth.
docs.snippet: When a dolphin is within weeks of giving birth, she faces a drastic increase in drag and changes the way she swims.

docs.lead_paragraph: Swedish researchers discovered that clamping a newborn’s umbilical cord after three minutes, rather than 10 seconds, meant the infants had higher iron concentrations in their blood four months later.

headline.seo: Delay in Clamping Umbilical Cord Has Benefits Months Later
headline.main: Childbirth: Benefits Seen in Clamping the Cord Later
headline.print_headline: Childbirth: Benefits Seen in Clamping the Cord Later

docs.abstract: Study published in journal BMJ finds waiting three minutes, rather than 10 seconds, before clamping a newborn's umbilical cord results in much lower incidence of blood iron deficiency four months later; pediatrician Ola Andersson is study's lead author.
docs.snippet: Swedish researchers discovered that clamping a newborn’s umbilical cord after three minutes, rather than 10 seconds, meant the infants had higher iron concentrations in their blood four months later.
